sn11.18:1.3.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo mātaliṃ saṅgāhakaṃ āmantesi:
sn11.18:1.3.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his chariot handler Mātali,

sn11.18:1.4.pli: ‘yojehi, samma mātali, sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ. Uyyānabhūmiṃ gacchāma subhūmiṃ dassanāyā’ti.
sn11.18:1.4.eng: ‘My dear Mātali, harness the chariot with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds. We will go to a park and see the scenery.’
sn11.18:1.4.comm: Indra’s thousandfold team of horses evoke the swift, thundering storm (Rig Veda 6.47.18, 7.91.6).

sn11.18:1.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ yojetvā sakkassa devānamindassa paṭivedesi:
sn11.18:1.5.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. He harnessed the chariot and informed Sakka,

sn11.18:1.6.eng: ‘Good fellow, the chariot with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds has been harnessed.

sn11.18:1.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo vejayantapāsādā orohanto añjaliṃ katvā sudaṃ puthuddisā namassati.
sn11.18:1.8.eng: Then Sakka descended from the Palace of Victory, raised his joined palms, and revered the various quarters.
sn11.18:1.8.comm: As does Sigālaka in DN 31:1.3, where they are specified as east, south, west, north, below, and above. Gods were often revered in particular quarters (eg. Atharva Veda 19.17).

sn11.18:1.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.18:1.9.eng: So Mātali the chariot handler addressed Sakka in verse:

sn11.18:2.1.eng: ‘Those proficient in the three Vedas worship you,

sn11.18:2.2.eng: as do all the aristocrats on earth,

sn11.18:2.4.eng: and the glorious host of Thirty.

sn11.18:2.5.eng: So what’s the name of the spirit

sn11.18:3.1.eng: ‘Those proficient in the three Vedas worship me,

sn11.18:3.2.eng: as do all the aristocrats on earth,

sn11.18:3.4.eng: and the glorious host of Thirty.

sn11.18:4.1.eng: But I revere those accomplished in ethics,

sn11.18:4.2.eng: who have long trained in immersion,

sn11.18:4.4.eng: for the culmination of spiritual life.

sn11.18:5.4.eng: providing for a partner in a principled manner.’

sn11.18:6.2.eng: seem to be the best in the world, Sakka.

sn11.18:7.1.eng: After saying this, Maghavā the chief,

sn11.19:1.2.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo mātaliṃ saṅgāhakaṃ āmantesi:
sn11.19:1.2.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his chariot handler Mātali,

sn11.19:1.3.pli: ‘yojehi, samma mātali, sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ, uyyānabhūmiṃ gacchāma subhūmiṃ dassanāyā’ti.
sn11.19:1.3.eng: ‘My dear Mātali, harness the chariot with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds. We will go to a park and see the scenery.’

sn11.19:1.4.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ yojetvā sakkassa devānamindassa paṭivedesi:
sn11.19:1.4.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. He harnessed the chariot and informed Sakka,

sn11.19:1.5.eng: ‘Good fellow, the chariot with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds has been harnessed.

sn11.19:1.7.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo vejayantapāsādā orohanto añjaliṃ katvā sudaṃ bhagavantaṃ namassati.
sn11.19:1.7.eng: Then Sakka descended from the Palace of Victory, raised his joined palms, and revered the Buddha.

sn11.19:1.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.19:1.8.eng: So Mātali the chariot handler addressed Sakka in verse:

sn11.19:2.3.eng: So what’s the name of the spirit

sn11.19:3.3.eng: in this world with its gods—

sn11.19:4.1.eng: Those in whom greed, hate, and ignorance

sn11.19:4.3.eng: the perfected ones with defilements ended—

sn11.19:5.1.eng: The trainees who enjoy reducing suffering,
sn11.19:5.1.comm: Read rāgadosavinayā and avijjāsamatikkamā as truncated dative of purpose (see SN 11.4:7.3).

sn11.19:5.3.eng: for getting rid of greed and hate,

sn11.19:6.2.eng: seem to be the best in the world, Sakka.

sn11.19:7.1.eng: After saying this, Maghavā the chief,

sn11.2:1.1.comm: Apart from the change of name, this discourse is identical to the previous.

sn11.2:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn11.2:2.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, the titans marched against the gods.

sn11.2:2.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo susīmaṃ devaputtaṃ āmantesi:
sn11.2:2.2.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the godling Susīma,
sn11.2:2.2.comm: A deity Susīma praises Sāriputta at SN 2.29:4.1.

sn11.2:2.3.eng: ‘Dear Susīma, the titans march against the gods!

sn11.2:2.4.eng: Go, and march against the titans!’

sn11.2:2.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, susīmo devaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā pamādaṃ āpādesi.
sn11.2:2.5.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Susīma. But he fell into negligence.

sn11.2:2.6.pli: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo susīmaṃ devaputtaṃ āmantesi …pe…

sn11.2:2.8.pli: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo susīmaṃ devaputtaṃ āmantesi …pe…

sn11.2:2.10.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo susīmaṃ devaputtaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.2:2.10.eng: Then Sakka addressed the godling Susīma in verse:

sn11.2:3.3.eng: without working for it or trying hard—

sn11.2:4.1.eng: ‘That a lazy man who does no work,

sn11.2:5.2.eng: where a lazy man who does no work

sn11.2:6.2.eng: that we might find the happiness

sn11.2:7.2.eng: where one can live happily without working,

sn11.2:7.3.eng: that surely would be extinguishment’s path!

sn11.2:8.1.pli: So hi nāma, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sakaṃ puññaphalaṃ upajīvamāno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kārento uṭṭhānavīriyassa vaṇṇavādī bhavissati.
sn11.2:8.1.eng: Since, mendicants, even that Sakka, lord of gods—while living off of the fruit of his good deeds, and ruling as sovereign lord over these gods of the thirty-three—will speak in praise of initiative and energy,

sn11.2:8.2.pli: Idha kho taṃ, bhikkhave, sobhetha, yaṃ tumhe evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajitā samānā uṭṭhaheyyātha ghaṭeyyātha vāyameyyātha appattassa pattiyā, anadhigatassa adhigamāya, asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
sn11.2:8.2.eng: you can excel at this, for you who have gone forth in such a well explained teaching and training can try hard, strive, and make an effort to attain the unattained, achieve the unachieved, and realize the unrealized.”

sn11.20:1.3.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo mātaliṃ saṅgāhakaṃ āmantesi:
sn11.20:1.3.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his chariot handler Mātali,

sn11.20:1.4.pli: ‘yojehi, samma mātali, sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ, uyyānabhūmiṃ gacchāma subhūmiṃ dassanāyā’ti.
sn11.20:1.4.eng: ‘My dear Mātali, harness the chariot with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds. We will go to a park and see the scenery.’

sn11.20:1.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā, sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ yojetvā sakkassa devānamindassa paṭivedesi:
sn11.20:1.5.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. He harnessed the chariot and informed Sakka,

sn11.20:1.6.eng: ‘Good fellow, the chariot with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds has been harnessed.

sn11.20:1.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo vejayantapāsādā orohanto añjaliṃ katvā sudaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ namassati.
sn11.20:1.8.eng: Then Sakka descended from the Palace of Victory, raised his joined palms, and revered the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn11.20:1.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.20:1.9.eng: So Mātali the chariot handler addressed Sakka in verse:

sn11.20:2.2.eng: namely the humans stuck in their putrid bodies,

sn11.20:3.1.eng: Why then do you envy those

sn11.20:3.2.comm: Mātali deploys this epithet very precisely. Vāsava, originally meaning “wealthy one” is interpreted in Pali as the “houser” (SN 11.12:4.1). Both senses draw on Indra’s bounty, which he generously bestows on his acolytes. Mātali implies that, since renunciates have no home, they must have been deficient in their worship. The narrative hinges on the shift from the Vedic religion of prosperity to the Buddhist value of letting go.

sn11.20:3.3.eng: Relate the seers’ way of life,

sn11.20:3.4.eng: let us hear what you say.’

sn11.20:5.1.eng: They hoard no goods in storerooms,

sn11.20:5.3.eng: They seek food prepared by others,
sn11.20:5.3.comm: “Prepared by others” is paraniṭṭhita. The same phrase is at Thig 13.2:13.3, where it is spelled pari-, but I assume they should both be para (“other”). Mendicants do not cook, but rely on what is cooked by others.

sn11.20:5.4.eng: and, true to their vows, live on that.

sn11.20:6.1.eng: The attentive, whose words are full of wisdom,

sn11.20:6.4.eng: and mortals fight each other, Mātali.

sn11.20:7.1.eng: Not fighting among those who fight,

sn11.20:7.2.eng: quenched among those who have taken up arms,

sn11.20:7.3.eng: not grasping among those who grasp:

sn11.20:8.2.eng: seem to be the best in the world, Sakka.

sn11.20:9.1.eng: After saying this, Maghavā the chief,

sn11.21:1.2.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn11.21:1.2.eng: And then Sakka, lord of gods, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,

sn11.21:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:

sn11.21:2.1.eng: “When what is slain do you sleep at ease?

sn11.21:2.2.eng: When what is slain is there no sorrow?

sn11.21:3.1.eng: “When anger’s slain you sleep at ease.

sn11.21:3.2.eng: When anger’s slain there is no sorrow.

sn11.21:3.4.eng: and a honey tip, O Vāsava.

sn11.21:3.5.eng: The noble ones praise its killing,

sn11.21:3.6.eng: for when it’s slain there is no sorrow.”

sn11.22:1.3.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, aññataro yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno ahosi.
sn11.22:1.3.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a native spirit who was ugly and deformed. He sat on the throne of Sakka, lord of gods.

sn11.22:1.4.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti:
sn11.22:1.4.eng: But the gods of the thirty-three complained, grumbled, and objected,

sn11.22:1.6.pli: Ayaṃ yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno’ti.
sn11.22:1.6.eng: This ugly and deformed spirit is sitting on the throne of Sakka, the lord of gods.’

sn11.22:1.7.pli: Yathā yathā kho, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti tathā tathā so yakkho abhirūpataro ceva hoti dassanīyataro ca pāsādikataro ca.
sn11.22:1.7.eng: But the more the gods complained, the more attractive, good-looking, and lovely that spirit became.

sn11.22:2.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn11.22:2.1.eng: So the gods went up to Sakka and told him what had happened. Indra replied,

sn11.22:2.2.pli: ‘idha te, mārisa, aññataro yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno.

sn11.22:2.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, mārisa, devā tāvatiṃsā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti:

sn11.22:2.5.pli: Ayaṃ yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno”ti.

sn11.22:2.6.pli: Yathā yathā kho, mārisa, devā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti tathā tathā so yakkho abhirūpataro ceva hoti dassanīyataro ca pāsādikataro cāti.

sn11.22:2.7.pli: So hi nūna, mārisa, kodhabhakkho yakkho bhavissatī’ti.
sn11.22:2.7.eng: ‘Surely, good fellow, that must be the anger-eating spirit!’
sn11.22:2.7.comm: That the speaker is Indra is confirmed by the vocative mārisa. Gods addressing Indra use bhaddantava.

sn11.22:3.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo yena so kodhabhakkho yakkho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalaṃ pathaviyaṃ nihantvā yena so kodhabhakkho yakkho tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ nāmaṃ sāveti:
sn11.22:3.1.eng: Then Sakka went up to that spirit, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt with his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms toward the anger-eating spirit, and pronounced his name three times:

sn11.22:3.2.eng: ‘Good fellow, I am Sakka, lord of gods! Good fellow, I am Sakka, the lord of gods!’

sn11.22:3.3.pli: Yathā yathā kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo nāmaṃ sāvesi tathā tathā so yakkho dubbaṇṇataro ceva ahosi okoṭimakataro ca.
sn11.22:3.3.eng: But the more Sakka pronounced his name, the uglier and more deformed the spirit became,

sn11.22:3.4.pli: Dubbaṇṇataro ceva hutvā okoṭimakataro ca tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn11.22:3.4.eng: until eventually it vanished right there.

sn11.22:3.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sake āsane nisīditvā deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn11.22:3.5.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the thirty-three, spoke this verse:

sn11.22:4.2.eng: I’m not easily drawn into the maelstrom.

sn11.22:4.3.eng: I don’t get angry for long,

sn11.22:5.1.eng: When I do get angry I don’t speak harshly,

sn11.22:5.2.eng: nor do I advertise my own virtues.

sn11.22:5.4.eng: out of regard for my own welfare.’”
sn11.22:5.4.comm: It’s notable not just how Sakka defuses the situation, but that he is full aware of how he does it, and uses his own conduct to inspire others.

sn11.23:1.3.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo ābādhiko ahosi dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn11.23:1.3.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Vepacitti, lord of titans, was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn11.23:1.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo yena vepacitti asurindo tenupasaṅkami gilānapucchako.
sn11.23:1.4.eng: So Sakka went to see him to ask after his illness.

sn11.23:1.5.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn11.23:1.5.eng: Vepacitti saw Sakka coming off in the distance,

sn11.23:1.7.comm: Such a tender and caring relationship between these erstwhile enemies.

sn11.23:1.8.comm: Sambara’s magic was legendary: shape-shifting (Śiva Purāṇa 59.19), battle-illusions (Viṣṇu Purāṇa 27, Harivaṁśa 99.27), rains of deadly weapons (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 10.21). None of these, however, suit Sakka’s behavior—he was not the sort to blackmail a mate in time of need. And indeed, there was a benevolent side to Sambara’s power as well. It was said to induce sleep (Arthaśāstra 14.3.19, 14.3.43), which could be a way to ease Vepacitti’s pain. There is also a hint of its medicinal use, since several medicinal herbs are named after it.

sn11.23:1.9.pli: ‘Na tāvāhaṃ vācemi, yāvāhaṃ, mārisa, asure paṭipucchāmī’ti.
sn11.23:1.9.eng: ‘I can’t do that, good fellow, until I have consulted with the titans.’
sn11.23:1.9.comm: Apparently demon society is quite democratic.

sn11.23:1.10.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo asure paṭipucchi:
sn11.23:1.10.eng: Then Vepacitti, lord of titans, asked the titans,

sn11.23:1.11.eng: ‘Good fellows, may I teach the Sambari sorcery to Sakka, lord of gods?’

sn11.23:1.12.pli: ‘Mā kho tvaṃ, mārisa, vācesi sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ sambarimāyan’ti.
sn11.23:1.12.eng: ‘Do not, good fellow, teach the Sambari sorcery to Sakka!’
sn11.23:1.12.comm: Understandable, given that it has military applications as well. Magic, like any other power, may be used for good or ill.

sn11.23:1.13.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.23:1.13.eng: So Vepacitti addressed Sakka in verse:

sn11.23:2.4.eng: into the terrible hell for a full century.’”
sn11.23:2.4.comm: Powerful magics come at a cost, and are unworthy of the lord of gods.

sn11.24:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dve bhikkhū sampayojesuṃ.
sn11.24:1.2.eng: Now at that time two mendicants had clashed.

sn11.24:1.3.eng: One of them transgressed against the other.

sn11.24:1.4.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu tassa bhikkhuno santike accayaṃ accayato deseti;
sn11.24:1.4.eng: The transgressor confessed to the other mendicant,

sn11.24:1.6.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn11.24:1.6.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn11.24:1.7.pli: “idha, bhante, dve bhikkhū sampayojesuṃ, tatreko bhikkhu accasarā.

sn11.24:1.8.pli: Atha kho so, bhante, bhikkhu tassa bhikkhuno santike accayaṃ accayato deseti, so bhikkhu nappaṭiggaṇhātī”ti.

sn11.24:2.1.comm: Also at AN 2.21. This procedure is formalized in the fortnightly confession between mendicants at the uposatha.

sn11.24:2.2.pli: Yo ca accayaṃ accayato na passati, yo ca accayaṃ desentassa yathādhammaṃ nappaṭiggaṇhāti—
sn11.24:2.2.eng: One who doesn’t recognize when they’ve made a mistake. And one who doesn’t properly accept the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.

sn11.24:2.4.eng: There are two who are astute.

sn11.24:2.5.pli: Yo ca accayaṃ accayato passati, yo ca accayaṃ desentassa yathādhammaṃ paṭiggaṇhāti—
sn11.24:2.5.eng: One who recognizes when they’ve made a mistake. And one who properly accepts the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.

sn11.24:2.6.eng: These are the two who are astute.

sn11.24:3.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sudhammāyaṃ sabhāyaṃ deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn11.24:3.1.eng: Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the thirty-three, spoke this verse:

sn11.24:4.2.comm: Read mittehi as locative plural.

sn11.25:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn11.25:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn11.25:1.3.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū …pe… bhagavā etadavoca:
sn11.25:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn11.25:1.4.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sudhammāyaṃ sabhāyaṃ deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn11.25:1.4.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the thirty-three, spoke this verse:

sn11.25:2.2.eng: don’t get angry at angry people.

sn11.25:2.4.eng: are always present in the noble ones.

sn11.25:3.5.eng: The Linked Discourses with Sakka are complete.

sn11.25:4.5.eng: The Book With Verses is finished.
